articles.headline: Airline Merger Talks Renew Skepticism of Tie-Ups
articles.snippet: The industry has a long history of botched mergers, given the difficulty of bringing together different flight networks, aircraft models and distinct cultures.
articles.abstract: The industry has a long history of botched mergers, given the difficulty of bringing together different flight networks, aircraft models and distinct cultures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the airline industry was deregulated more than three decades ago, the nation’s top carriers have operated under a basic premise: bigger is better.

articles.headline: South African Judge May Be Kept From Grandson’s Bar Mitzvah
articles.snippet: A vague threat of violence may mean Richard Goldstone, who led an inquiry into Israel’s invasion of Gaza, won’t attend a celebration for his grandson in a Johannesburg suburb.
articles.abstract: A vague threat of violence may mean Richard Goldstone, who led an inquiry into Israel’s invasion of Gaza, won’t attend a celebration for his grandson in a Johannesburg suburb.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — For the past few days, many South African Jews have concerned themselves with a question perhaps better put to Talmudic scholars: Is it ever right for protesters to keep a grandfather from his grandson’s bar mitzvah?

articles.headline: Veto Threat Raised Over Derivatives
articles.snippet: A sweeping bill from Senator Blanche Lincoln goes beyond the administration’s goals on regulating derivatives, and has met with strong resistance from Senate Republicans.
articles.abstract: A sweeping bill from Senator Blanche Lincoln goes beyond the administration’s goals on regulating derivatives, and has met with strong resistance from Senate Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama threatened on Friday to veto the financial overhaul bill making its way through Congress if it failed to include strong restrictions on derivatives, which were at the heart of the financial crisis two years ago.

articles.headline: Web Coupons Know Lots About You, and They Tell
articles.snippet: Printed or sent to cellphones, the coupons look standard, but they can contain a startling amount of data.
articles.abstract: Printed or sent to cellphones, the coupons look standard, but they can contain a startling amount of data.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, shoppers have taken advantage of coupons. Now, the coupons are taking advantage of the shoppers.

articles.headline: Reverse Mortgages Still Costly, but Less So
articles.snippet: The costs for reverse mortgages have declined, but that still doesn’t make them cheap.
articles.abstract: The costs for reverse mortgages have declined, but that still doesn’t make them cheap.
articles.lead_paragraph: The adage that you can’t take out a loan to pay for retirement is not entirely true.

articles.headline: Investor Who Made Billions Is Not Target of Suit
articles.snippet: John A. Paulson had a role in the instrument that caused $1 billion in losses for Goldman Sachs customers.
articles.abstract: John A. Paulson had a role in the instrument that caused $1 billion in losses for Goldman Sachs customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three and half years ago, a New York hedge fund manager with a bearish view on the housing market was pounding the pavement on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story

articles.headline: A Wall Street Invention Let the Crisis Mutate
articles.snippet: In the absence of financial instruments known as synthetic C.D.O.’s, the subprime crisis might have been more easily contained.
articles.abstract: In the absence of financial instruments known as synthetic C.D.O.’s, the subprime crisis might have been more easily contained.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can it get any worse?

articles.headline: Fleeing Drug Violence, Mexicans Pour Into U.S.
articles.snippet: Residents say drug gangs have laid waste to El Porvenir, Mexico, and those who can are fleeing to the U.S.
articles.abstract: Residents say drug gangs have laid waste to El Porvenir, Mexico, and those who can are fleeing to the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT HANCOCK, Tex. — The giant rusty fence of metal bars along the border here, built in recent years to keep illegal immigrants from crossing into the United States, has a new nickname among local residents: Jurassic Park Gate, a nod to the barrier in a 1993 movie that kept dangerous dinosaurs at bay in a theme park.

articles.headline: For Goldman, a Bet’s Stakes Keep Growing
articles.snippet: Accusations that Goldman defrauded customers who bought investments tied to risky mortgages have only just begun to reverberate in the financial world.
articles.abstract: Accusations that Goldman defrauded customers who bought investments tied to risky mortgages have only just begun to reverberate in the financial world.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Goldman Sachs, it was a relatively small transaction. But for the bank — and the rest of Wall Street — the stakes couldn’t be higher.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Why Newer Appointees Offer Fewer Surprises
articles.snippet: The contemporary Supreme Court nominee’s résumé yields so much valuable information, legal scholars say, that unexpected judicial decisions are much less likely.
articles.abstract: The contemporary Supreme Court nominee’s résumé yields so much valuable information, legal scholars say, that unexpected judicial decisions are much less likely.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last two justices to leave the Supreme Court, David H. Souter and Sandra Day O’Connor, were nominated by Republican presidents and then drifted left. So did Justice John Paul Stevens, who announced his retirement last week.

articles.headline: After Quake, Tibetans Distrust China’s Help
articles.snippet: Despite outward signs of ethnic unity, the earthquake has exposed stubborn tensions between Beijing and Tibetans.
articles.abstract: Despite outward signs of ethnic unity, the earthquake has exposed stubborn tensions between Beijing and Tibetans.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIEGU, China — The Buddhist monks stood atop the jagged remains of a vocational school, struggling to move concrete slabs with pickax shovels and bare hands. Suddenly a cry went out: An arm, clearly lifeless, was poking through the debris.

articles.headline: Out of the Loop in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: In the fast-moving world of high-tech start-ups, the number of women has been slow to change.
articles.abstract: In the fast-moving world of high-tech start-ups, the number of women has been slow to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: San Francisco

articles.headline: Trench Warfare: Send In the Deputies
articles.snippet: The Obama administration’s push for financial reform has three front-line generals who handle the day-in, day-out bargaining and drudgery that such efforts entail.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration’s push for financial reform has three front-line generals who handle the day-in, day-out bargaining and drudgery that such efforts entail.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

articles.headline: This Bailout Is a Bargain? Think Again
articles.snippet: There is talk that the price tag on Wall Street’s bailout will be relatively inexpensive. Too bad that leaves out many of the real costs.
articles.abstract: There is talk that the price tag on Wall Street’s bailout will be relatively inexpensive. Too bad that leaves out many of the real costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S way too early to tally the costs of the government’s various efforts to help our nation’s financial institutions survive the credit debacle. But that hasn’t stopped anonymous Treasury officials from claiming in recent days that their Armageddon-avoidance will wind up costing far less than many feared.

articles.headline: Gates Says U.S. Lacks a Policy to Thwart Iran
articles.snippet: A secret memo set off a search for new options in dealing with Iran’s steady progress toward nuclear capability.
articles.abstract: A secret memo set off a search for new options in dealing with Iran’s steady progress toward nuclear capability.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has warned in a secret three-page memorandum to top White House officials that the United States does not have an effective long-range policy for dealing with Iran’s steady progress toward nuclear capability, according to government officials familiar with the document.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Airlines Press Europe to Ease Ban on Flights
articles.snippet: As Europe grounded most airline flights for a fourth day, desperate airlines ran test flights and pressed aviation authorities to loosen the flight ban.
articles.abstract: As Europe grounded most airline flights for a fourth day, desperate airlines ran test flights and pressed aviation authorities to loosen the flight ban.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Europe grounded most airline flights for a fourth day on Sunday because of a volcanic ash cloud spreading from Iceland, increasingly desperate airlines ran test flights to show that flying was safe and pressed aviation authorities to loosen the flight ban.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: Companies Slowly Join Cloud-Computing
articles.snippet: Amazon, Microsoft, Google and others are now trying to rent large corporations the remote use of their technology infrastructure, but some concerns remain after a few cautious steps into cloud services.
articles.abstract: Amazon, Microsoft, Google and others are now trying to rent large corporations the remote use of their technology infrastructure, but some concerns remain after a few cautious steps into cloud services.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This year, Netflix made what looked like a peculiar choice: the DVD-by-mail company decided that over the next two years, it would move most of its Web technology — customer movie queues, search tools and the like — over to the computer servers of one of its chief rivals, Amazon.com.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Indian Who Built Yoga Empire Works on Politics
articles.snippet: Swami Ramdev, a yogic fusion of Richard Simmons, Dr. Oz and Oprah Winfrey, said he would establish a political party.
articles.abstract: Swami Ramdev, a yogic fusion of Richard Simmons, Dr. Oz and Oprah Winfrey, said he would establish a political party.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARIDWAR, India — The sun slumbered well beneath the horizon, but Swami Ramdev had been up for hours. Swathed in a saffron loincloth, he led his charges, a few hundred devotees in this holy city on the Ganges River and tens of millions more watching on television, through a rapid-fire series of yoga poses.

articles.headline: For Chinese, Web Is the Way to Entertainment
articles.snippet: The Internet, already a potent social force, has become the country’s prime entertainment service.
articles.abstract: The Internet, already a potent social force, has become the country’s prime entertainment service.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The daily Web habits of a typical 18-year-old college student named Li Yufei show why American Internet companies, one after another, have had trouble penetrating what is now the world’s most wired nation.

articles.headline: Senior Executives at Goldman Had a Role in Mortgage Unit
articles.snippet: As the bank deals with a fraud suit from the S.E.C., former workers say that in 2006, executives sided with traders who thought home prices would decline.
articles.abstract: As the bank deals with a fraud suit from the S.E.C., former workers say that in 2006, executives sided with traders who thought home prices would decline.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tensions were rising inside Goldman Sachs.

articles.headline: A Glare on Goldman, From U.S. and Beyond
articles.snippet: Two congressmen urged investigations into possible taxpayer losses related to Goldman deals, and the British prime minister asked his nation’s securities regulator to investigate.
articles.abstract: Two congressmen urged investigations into possible taxpayer losses related to Goldman deals, and the British prime minister asked his nation’s securities regulator to investigate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Calls for increased scrutiny of Goldman Sachs emerged on Sunday as two congressmen pressed for investigations into possible taxpayer losses generated in securities sold by the firm, and the British prime minister also asked his nation’s securities regulator to investigate the Wall Street powerhouse because of losses suffered by a major British bank.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: S.E.C. Puts Wall St. on Notice
articles.snippet: With its case against Goldman, the S.E.C. is sending a signal that it is back on the beat and that it is going after very big targets.
articles.abstract: With its case against Goldman, the S.E.C. is sending a signal that it is back on the beat and that it is going after very big targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the last few years, the Securities and Exchange Commission seemed like the cop in the doughnut shop, sitting idly by while the likes of Lehman Brothers and Bernard L. Madoff ran amok.

articles.headline: Democrats Seize on Financial Oversight After Goldman Suit
articles.snippet: Democrats are emboldened to ratchet up pressure on Republicans who oppose the financial overhaul bill.
articles.abstract: Democrats are emboldened to ratchet up pressure on Republicans who oppose the financial overhaul bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the Senate scheduled to begin debate on a financial overhaul bill this week, the fraud suit against the Wall Street titan Goldman Sachs has emboldened Democrats to ratchet up pressure on Republicans who oppose the Obama administration’s proposal.

articles.headline: White House Quietly Courts Muslims in U.S.
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has reached out to Muslims in a widening effort that has left even skeptics surprised.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has reached out to Muslims in a widening effort that has left even skeptics surprised.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Obama took the stage in Cairo last June, promising a new relationship with the Islamic world, Muslims in America wondered only half-jokingly whether the overture included them. After all, Mr. Obama had kept his distance during the campaign, never visiting an American mosque and describing the false claim that he was Muslim as a “smear” on his Web site.

articles.headline: People StyleWatch Gains as It Blurs Ad Lines
articles.snippet: People StyleWatch is booming as it tosses out old-fashioned ideas of what magazine editorial pages should contain and baldly sells products.
articles.abstract: People StyleWatch is booming as it tosses out old-fashioned ideas of what magazine editorial pages should contain and baldly sells products.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may be a dreary time in the magazine business, but you wouldn’t know it inside the offices of People StyleWatch, a bright spot in the industry. Here, on the 29th floor of the Time & Life building, it is girlie heaven, with flip-flops in pink patent leather, neon rubber lining the hallway, and a fashion closet that holds all the bronzing powder, chunky earrings and formal shorts (yes, it’s a thing) that shoppers daydream about.

articles.headline: Iraqi Court Sets Partial Recount in Tight Election
articles.snippet: The ruling may help Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki keep his office after his bloc finished a close second in parliamentary voting.
articles.abstract: The ruling may help Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki keep his office after his bloc finished a close second in parliamentary voting.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — An Iraqi court on Monday ordered a partial recount of votes in last month’s national election, deepening the political turmoil that many here feared could turn violent when the United States begins to withdraw most of its combat troops this summer.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Tim Arango
